title-group.article-title: Efficient broadcasting using packet history in mobile ad hoc networks

abstract.p: Broadcasting is a key component of several networking mechanisms in mobile ad hoc networks. However, its traditional implementation suffers from resource consumption caused by message redundancy. Several efficient algorithms have been proposed to tackle this problem. Among them, the class of algorithms that construct on-demand a connected dominating set, known as dominant pruning, yields an improved performance. Dominant pruning algorithms capitalise on neighbourhood information and the previous hop of the broadcast message in order to minimise the set of nodes that forward a message. The proposed algorithm makes the observation that all the nodes, visited by a broadcast message, may be exploited in order to minimise the cost of broadcasting. The analysis of the proposed algorithm as well as extensive simulation results confirm the rationale behind the proposed approach and prove the performance gains.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays the use of wireless mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs) for supporting temporary communication needs has been spread in various application scenarios. However, protocols used in wired networks cannot be ported in wireless networks due to mobility and the nature of wireless transmission. In wired networks, topology remains constant whereas in wireless mobile networks nodes can move to any direction producing topology variations. As a result, communication is hard or even impossible to be established. Many wireless networking protocols use broadcasting for adapting to topology variations. For example, many routing [1] and multicast [2] algorithms use network layer broadcasting in order to discover a new route or send a route invalidation message. Therefore a cost-effective broadcasting mechanism is required. Flooding is the most popular technique for reliable broadcasting because of its simple implementation. However, a study of pure flooding brought to surface the broadcast storm problem [3] and made clear that the limited bandwidth and energy resources necessitate the design of efficient communication protocols.

Several research groups have dealt with efficient broadcasting. The proposed algorithms can be classified into three categories: (a) heuristic, (b) cluster-based and (c) minimum connected dominating set (CDS) approximations. The objective of all schemes is to eliminate redundant transmissions by minimising the set of nodes that forward packets. Heuristic schemes [3–9] utilise probabilistic parameters that depend mainly on topology-based criteria in order to determine the nodes allowed to forward packets. The drawback of heuristic algorithms is the difficulty in fine-tuning the probabilistic parameters [10] in order to guarantee message delivery even to poorly connected networks. In cluster-based schemes [11], broadcasting is performed by cluster heads and gateway nodes. More specifically, cluster heads are responsible for delivering packets inside clusters, whereas gateways propagate packets between clusters. However, in this approach, cluster heads and gateways become points of congestion. As a result, cluster-based broadcasting may not fit with some applications. For example, when flooding is used as part of an on-demand routing protocol, congestion points should be avoided. Furthermore, clusters are susceptible to mobility; therefore their maintenance induces increased cost.

Another approach is to use a CDS for broadcasting [12–25]. The idea is to permit only nodes that belong to the CDS to forward packets. The objective is to reduce the size of the calculated CDS in order to achieve optimal transmission overhead. The CDS may be constructed on a proactive [12–14, 17, 18] or reactive (on-demand) fashion [19–23] or may be based on global positioning satellite (GPS) information [24, 25]. Hybrid approaches that combine heuristic and CDS-based approaches have also been proposed [26]. Recent works include CDS-based approaches that incorporate network-coding [27] and directional antennas [28]. In this paper, we focus on the subclass of algorithms that construct a CDS on an on-demand basis, known as dominant pruning (DP). This class of algorithms has been identified to provide a flexible and low overhead solution [29]. In DP, each node v, receiving a broadcast message from node u, determines a CDS valid for its 2-hop neighbourhood by electing 1-hop neighbours that are allowed to forward the message. The election is carried out by a pruning process that exploits the neighbourhood of nodes v and u in order to minimise the calculated CDS [20, 21]. The approach is based on the observation that the neighbours of u should not be considered because they have already received the message.

Although the DP approach has been proved to be effective, using only the neighbourhood of the previous hop node clearly provides an underestimation of the nodes that have already received the message. Providing a better estimation should result in performance improvement. In this paper, we make the observation that the set of nodes visited by a message in its travel from the source node to a node v provides a good basis for estimating the nodes that have already received this message. Therefore the set of these nodes may be utilised by the pruning process in order to minimise the constructed CDS. The proposed algorithm, called history-based 2-hop dominant pruning (H2DP), exploits the neighbourhood of each node visited by a broadcast message in order to ameliorate broadcasting. We provide an analysis of H2DP that justifies our approach while an extensive simulation study confirms its improved performance compared to total dominant pruning (TDP), partial dominant pruning (PDP) [21] and DP [20] protocols, which are the most representative of the DP category and yield the best performance. Finally, we propose an optimisation of H2DP, called history-based dominant pruning (HDP), which is tailored for sparse and highly mobile networks.

The rest of this paper is organised as follows. In Section 2, we provide useful notation and briefly describe DP. Then, in Section 3, H2DP is delineated while its complexity analysis is presented and discussed. In Section 4, we describe the model used in the simulation study, while in Section 5 simulation results are presented and discussed. The optimisation of H2DP for sparse highly mobile networks is presented in Section 6. Finally, in Section 7 useful conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Preliminaries
sec.p:
H2DP falls into the category of DP algorithms. Therefore before delineating its operation, we formulate the problem of DP. To this end, the following notation is employed:
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).

In DP, each node v maintains knowledge about N(N(v)) by exchanging with its neighbours periodic hello messages that contain 1-hop neighbourhood information. In order to forward a broadcast message, node v calculates a subset of N(v), called the forwarding set, and piggybacks it on the message.
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).
Definition 1: Forwarding set of node v (Fw(v))
The subset of N(v) consists of neighbours that are allowed to forward a message.

In DP's approach, Fw(v) is a CDS of the graph N(N(v)), therefore all nodes in N(N(v)) will receive the message after it is forwarded by all nodes in Fw(v). Each node w∈Fw(v), after receiving the message, repeats the procedure. The CDS for the entire network consists of the forwarding sets computed locally by each node. The algorithm terminates either when w∉Fw(v) or when node w∈Fw(v) but a termination criterion is met. Two termination criteria have been proposed [21], namely relayed/unrelayed and marked/unmarked. The latter specifies that node w should not forward the message if all nodes in N(w) have already received it, whereas the former mandates that node w forwards a message only once. In this paper we will focus on the relayed/unrelayed criterion since it provides a low-cost implementation compared to the marked/unmarked criterion [21].
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).

The calculation of Fw(v) at node v, for a packet coming from node u, involves two sets, namely B(v) and U(v).
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).

statement.label: Definition 2: Broadcast candidate set of node v (B(v))
statement.p: A subset of N(v) consists of nodes that are candidates for forwarding a message.

statement.label: Definition 3: Universal set of node v (U(v))
statement.p: A subset of N(N(v)) comprising nodes that should receive the broadcast message after it is forwarded by all nodes in Fw(v). The term universal refers to the vicinity of v and not to the entire network.

sec.title: History-based H2DP
sec.p:
H2DP falls into the category of algorithms that construct on-demand an approximation of a minimum CDS by utilising the DP approach. Moreover, H2DP introduces the concept of packet history. Let us consider the case that a packet p is received by a node v after being transmitted by node u. The term packet is used to refer to a copy of a broadcast message. However, in some parts the terms packet and message are used interchangeably. The packet history consists of the nodes that have already received p. More specifically, the history Hv(p) is defined as:
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).
N(u) denotes the set of nodes that lie 1-hop away from node u, including u itself, and is called the 1-hop neighbourhood of u.
N(N(u)) denotes the 2-hop neighbourhood of node u, that is, the set of nodes that lie within two hops from node u. Clearly, N(u)⊆N(N(u)).

statement.label: Definition 4: Packet history Hv(p)
statement.p: The set of nodes that have received packet p in its travel along pv(p) while the packet route pv(p) is defined as:

statement.label: Definition 5: Packet route pv(p)
statement.p: The set of forward nodes that packet p has visited from the source node s to node v, including v.

sec.p:
According to H2DP's approach, reducing the size of the universal set U(v) holds a central role in minimising the number of elected forwarding nodes and therefore in alleviating the cost of broadcasting. To this end, H2DP makes the observation that U(v) may contain nodes that have already received p (i.e. they belong to the packet's history), therefore such nodes may be eliminated from U(v). More specifically, upon reception of p coming from node u, v examines the forwarding list Fw(u) which is piggybacked on p's header. If v∉Fw(u) then the packet is discarded. Otherwise, v calculates B(v)=N(v)−N(u) and $$U\lpar v\rpar =N\lpar N\lpar v\rpar \rpar - H^u \lpar p\rpar \eqno (1)$$
and constructs Fw(v) by utilising GSC. In the special case that v is the source node s, B(s)=N(s) and U(s)=N(N(s)). Determining the nodes in packet history is clearly very important for the performance of H2DP. The simplest approach is to consider only the nodes in Pu(p), that is, Hu(p)=Pu(p). This approach has been proposed in the literature of non-dominant pruning schemes [32] on the basis that only those nodes are proved to have received p. However, this approach provides an underestimation of the nodes that have actually received the packet and has a negligible impact on reducing U(v) since usually |Pu(p)|=|U(v)|. On the other hand, H2DP makes the observation that each node w in Pu(p) is a forwarding node. Therefore all nodes in N(N(w)) have been scheduled to receive the packet by the execution of the algorithm at w. Consequently, in H2DP $$H^u \lpar p\rpar =\bigcup\limits_{\forall w \in P^u \lpar p\rpar } N\lpar N\lpar w\rpar \rpar \eqno(2)$$

After calculating Fw(v), node v updates packet history $$H^v \lpar p\rpar =H^u \lpar p\rpar \cup N\lpar N\lpar v\rpar \rpar \eqno(3)$$
and piggybacks Fw(v) and Hv(p) on the packet's header. The algorithm terminates either when p has been forwarded by v in the past or when v∉Fw(u).

The concept of history in H2DP and its impact on the determination of U(v) is depicted in Fig. 1a. In H2DP, node v makes the assumption that, given a node w∈Pu(p), all nodes in N(N(w)) have received packet p. This is the same assumption as the one made by TDP if w is the previous hop node (Fig. 1b). However, H2DP results in a smaller universal set U(v) because it makes the aforementioned assumption ∀w∈Pu(p). The correctness of H2DP's approach can be proved by the following theorem:

caption.p: When executed at a node v. Arrows indicate the path followed by the broadcast message

statement.label: Theorem 1
statement.p: If a node w∈N(N(v)) and w∈Hu(p) then w can be excluded from U(v).

statement.label: Proof
statement.p: Since node w∈Hu(p) this means that there exists a node f∈Pu(p) for which w∈N(f) or w∈N(N(f)). In the first case the transmission by f, which is a forward node, delivers the packet to w. In the second case, f has elected a forwarder for covering w therefore w receives the packet after the transmission by this forwarder. In the special case that f is the previous hop node (f=u) and node v is elected as the forwarder for covering w this means that w∈N(v), therefore the transmission by v delivers the message to w. If the termination criterion at v has already been met (v has already forwarded p) this means that all nodes in N(v) (including w) have already received the packet. □

sec.p: In the following, it will be shown that reducing U(v) allows H2DP to minimise the number of nodes that need to forward a message while at the same time the algorithm is executed in a smaller amount of time. Both of these characteristics are very important in the energy constrained context of a MANET. Moreover, reducing the number of transmissions economises on scarce network resources, such as bandwidth, and alleviates contention and/or congestion on the wireless medium.

sec.title: Complexity analysis
sec.p: All DP algorithms, including H2DP, rely on GSC to implement the forwarder selection process. GSC provides an approximation of the optimal solution since the set cover problem is known to be NP-hard [30]. Consequently, all algorithms inherit the approximation nature of GSC. However, the performance and time complexity of each DP scheme depends on the sets B and U that each algorithm provides as input to GSC. In the following, we analyse the performance of H2DP when executed at a node v and compare it with other DP schemes.

Time complexity: GSC is a polynomial time algorithm known to run in time [30] $$O\lpar \vert U\lpar v\rpar \vert \vert B\lpar v\rpar \vert \min \lcub \vert U\lpar v\rpar \vert \comma \; \vert B\lpar v\rpar \vert \rcub \rpar \eqno(4)$$

However, a linear time implementation is possible [30, 31] that runs in time $$O\left({\sum\limits_{\forall v_i \in B\lpar v\rpar } \vert N\lpar v_i \rpar \cap U\lpar v\rpar \vert } \right)\eqno(5)$$
Theorem 2
H2DP has an improved time complexity compared to TDP, PDP and DP. Proof
Let us define by UH(v) and UT(v) the universal sets for H2DP and TDP, respectively. In the following, we will use the superscripts H, T, P and D to indicate that the referenced quantity refers to H2DP, TDP, PDP and DP, respectively. It is clear from (1) that UH(v)⊆UT(v) because N(N(u))⊆Hu(p). Since B(v) is common for both schemes
$$\lpar N\lpar v_i \rpar \cap U^H \lpar v\rpar \rpar \subseteq \lpar N\lpar v_i \rpar \cap U^T \lpar v\rpar \rpar \comma \; \quad \forall v_i \in B\lpar v\rpar \eqno(6)$$

Therefore |(N(vi)∩UH(v))|≤|(N(vi)∩UT(v))|, ∀vi∈B(v) and based on (5) it is clear that the time complexity of H2DP is better than that of TDP. Similarly, it can be proved that H2DP has an improved time complexity compared to PDP and DP. □

Forwarding complexity: The cost of broadcasting is related to the number of elected forwarding nodes. GSC is used for the election process, providing an approximation of the optimal solution with an approximation factor ρ known to be [30] $$\rho=H\lpar \max \lcub \vert N\lpar v_i \rpar \cap U\lpar v\rpar \vert \colon \forall v_i \in B\lpar v\rpar \rcub \rpar \eqno(7)$$
where $H\lpar k\rpar =\Sigma _{i=1}^k \lpar 1/i\rpar $. Since $\Sigma _{i=1}^k \lpar 1/i\rpar \leq \ln \lpar k+1\rpar $ and |N(vi)∩U(v)|≤|U(v)|, ∀vi∈B(v), the approximation factor ρ can also be expressed as [30] $$\rho=\ln \lpar \vert U\lpar v\rpar \vert +1\rpar \eqno(8)$$

Equations (7) and (8) prove that the performance of each DP scheme at node v depends on the determination of B(v) and U(v). Theorem 3
The approximation factor ρH of H2DP is better or equal to the approximation factor ρT of TDP. Proof
In the case that node v is the source node s or v∈N(s), U(s) is the same for both schemes. More specifically, UH(s)=UT(s)=N(N(s)), whereas UH(v)=UT(v)=N(N(v))−N(N(s)), ∀≠s∈N(s). Consequently, according to (7), the approximation factor for both schemes is the same. On the contrary, when the DP algorithm is executed at any node v∉N(s) for a packet p received from node u then
$$\eqalign{U^{\rm H} \lpar v\rpar & =N\lpar N\lpar v\rpar \rpar - H^u \lpar p\rpar \cr & \subseteq N\lpar N\lpar v\rpar \rpar - N\lpar N\lpar u\rpar \rpar =U^{\rm T} \lpar v\rpar } \eqno(9)$$
Consequently, |UH(v)|≤|UT(v)| and according to (7) ρH≤ρT. Similarly, it can also be proved that H2DP exhibits a better approximation factor than that of PDP and DP. □

sec.title: Representation of packet history and neighbourhood information
sec.p: The method used for representing the packet history is a key performance factor of H2DP. The reason is twofold. On the one hand, the history size affects the packet size. The simulation study presented in the following confirms that even if a raw representation method is used (i.e. each node is represented by its address), H2DP produces packets of reasonable size even for large networks. However, reducing the packet size is a challenging objective, which should be combined with the alleviation of computational overheads related to operations on the packet history and/or the universal set such as search, addition and deletion. Equations (1)–(3) indicate that a node is frequently involved in such operations. For example, suppose that a node v receives a packet p from node u. The calculation of U(v) involves searching whether each node w∈N(N(v)) is a member of Hu(p). Such computational overheads also exist in all other DP schemes but have never been addressed.

It is clear that a more elaborate representation method for packet history and possibly for neighbourhood information should provide size minimisation as well as fast search, addition and deletion operations. To this end, we propose the use of bit arrays or bit vectors. Bit arrays are the simplest way to implement direct addressing [30] in which dictionary operations are executed in O(1) time. In our implementation, a bit vector of size S may be used to represent a set of S nodes. A bit set to 1 indicates that a node is a member of the set. The network addressing scheme, for example, IP addressing, may be used to provide one-to-one mapping of node addresses to bit vector indexes. This mapping can be predefined if all possible members of the set are known. It is clear that all network nodes may be members of a packet history. Therefore in order to use bit vectors, the size of the vector S should be equal to the maximum network size, that is, S=N. This results in a requirement of N bits for a network of N nodes. For a 200-node network, the required history size is 25 bytes which is rather small; only a set of six nodes could be represented with the same amount of bytes if IP addressing is assumed and the whole address is stored. Therefore bit arrays may also provide efficient compression of packet history.

sec.title: Set up and methodology
sec.p: The performance of H2DP is assessed through comparison with TDP, PDP and DP algorithms which are known to yield the best performance in the DP class of algorithms. In broadcast algorithms, like those investigated in this paper, simulating realistic network conditions is of great importance. This is because packets are transmitted through MAC layer broadcasts, therefore packet collisions result in packet drops. Collisions also have an impact on hello messages and therefore affect the accuracy of the neighbourhood information. Furthermore, congestion may also result in packet losses and/or delay. In this work, we used the medium access control of IEEE 802.11, provided in the CMU extension of ns2 [33], in order to approximate realistic network conditions. Moreover, we used configurations of high mobility in order to assess the resilience of the algorithms to stale neighbourhood information. All presented results were obtained as average values over 20 independent simulation runs. The simulation time for each run was 900 s. The confidence level for all reported results is 95%. The simulation parameters are summarised in Table 1.

sec.title: Network model
sec.p: The network consists of N nodes that roam in a square area. The transmission range of each node is set to R=250 m while the nominal bitrate is set to 2 Mb/s. Mobility scenarios have been produced using the well-known random waypoint (RW) algorithm and the perfect simulation model [34] in order to avoid transient artefacts in nodes’ movement. We consider a ‘sparse’ and a ‘dense’ network topology. The ‘sparse’ topology corresponds to a low-density network in which a node has only one neighbour in the worst case while the average number of neighbours is 15. On the other hand, in the ‘dense’ network topology the node density is twice the density of the ‘sparse’ topology, that is, the average number of neighbours is 30. In order to control the node density and produce ‘sparse’ and ‘dense’ topologies, we used square roaming areas of different size depending on the number of nodes N. The actual size of the roaming area is derived through the node distribution proposed for the RW algorithm in [35] and the calculation of node degree is proposed in [36].

sec.title: Packet generation
sec.p: Thirty broadcast sessions are considered in total, each one stemming from a different source node. Each session periodically produces broadcast messages at a rate λ. The size of each broadcast message has been set to 256 bytes.

sec.title: Algorithm-specific parameters
sec.p: Each node maintains 2-hop neighbourhood information by periodically exchanging hello messages with an interval of tH seconds. A neighbour is removed if a hello message has not been received within 2tH seconds since the last update. An important issue related to broadcast schemes is the jittering required for avoiding collisions of duplicate packets [29]. In order to have a fair comparison of all algorithms, we chose a random jittering scheme with the maximum jitter set to 0.1 s. Regarding history representation, the optimisation presented in Section 3.2 has not been used in order to capture the worst-case performance of H2DP. Instead, we used 4 bytes for representing a node in the forwarding set or in the packet history. This size is sufficient for storing addresses even if an IP-based addressing scheme is considered.

sec.title: Simulation study and analysis
sec.p: In the first experiment, we evaluate the performance of H2DP against the network size in dense and sparse networks under low mobility (1 m/s) and traffic load (0.2 pkts/s). Fig. 2 illustrates the number of forward nodes, that is, the average number of nodes that forward a broadcast message, for all the investigated algorithms. H2DP outperforms all other schemes for all network sizes in both the dense and the sparse topologies. H2DP's performance in small networks (less than 75 nodes) is almost equivalent to that of TDP (and PDP), especially in the case of dense networks. The reason is that most nodes are within two hops from the source node s. As a result, H2DP works mainly in the first hop, therefore the history of a packet p at a node v∈N(s) consists only of N(N(s)), that is, Hs(p)≡N(N(s)). In this case, according to (1), the operation of H2DP is identical to that of TDP and close to the operation of PDP. When the network size increases, many nodes are located more than one hop away from s, that is, a route Pv(p) to a node v contains more hops on average. Therefore according to (2), the packet history is populated by more nodes. Consequently, U(v) is effectively reduced and the approximation factor of GSC improves (see (7)), resulting in reduced forwarding sets. On the other hand, the improvement of TDP and PDP compared to DP is smaller than that of H2DP and remains approximately the same for all network sizes. This can be ascribed to the strategy of both algorithms to only take advantage of the previous hop u in order to minimise the universal set at node v (TDP only uses N(N(u)) whereas PDP utilises N(N(v)∩N(u))). This strategy cannot take advantage of the longer paths that a packet travels as the network size increases. TDP reduces forward nodes by ∼22% compared to DP; PDP improves by ∼14% whereas H2DP manages a gain up to ∼46%. The improvement compared to DP is less intense for all schemes in the sparse topology (∼26, ∼14 and ∼10% for H2DP, TDP and PDP, respectively) due to the reduced neighbourhood size.

caption.p: Number of forward nodes against network size (1 m/s, 0.2 pkts/s, tH=2 s)#a Dense topology

sec.p: It must be noted that the tradeoff for the improvement witnessed in TDP, PDP and H2DP with respect to DP is the increased computational and space requirements due to the extensive use of 2-hop neighbourhood information. However, the representation method proposed in Section 3.2 may be used in order to effectively alleviate the space as well as the computational requirements related to the use of 2-hop neighbourhood.

Fig. 3 depicts the delivery ratio, that is, the percentage of network nodes that receive a broadcast message. This metric is of great importance in contention-based and mobile networks. All schemes present a high delivery ratio near to 100% for small dense networks (Fig. 3a). However, in large dense networks there is a rapid performance degradation because of congestion and packet collisions. Since the packet generation rate is relatively low (only 0.2 pkts/s), congestion is the result of packet redundancy produced by the algorithms. This is confirmed by Fig. 4 where the packets received per node, that is, the average number of duplicate packets of a broadcast message received by a node, is illustrated. Indeed, more duplicate packets are produced for large dense networks since there are more forwarding nodes (Fig. 2a) and more disjoint paths through which packet duplicates may reach a node. In small networks, both H2DP and TDP achieve better delivery ratio compared to DP since both protocols minimise congestion. On the contrary, in large networks TDP fails to reduce congestion to the same extent as H2DP does (Fig. 5). The same applies to DP and PDP; however, their increased packet redundancy compensates for packet losses due to congestion and results in a slower degradation of the delivery ratio compared to TDP. However, this is not enough to outperform H2DP which effectively reduces network load even for large networks and achieves the highest delivery ratio. Similar performance characteristics are witnessed for sparse networks. However, differences are smoothed out since the reduced connectivity induces less congestion for all schemes. Finally, concerning Fig. 4, we should point out that packet redundancy is related to the node's energy consumption since packet reception and processing involves an energy cost. Consequently, Fig. 4 reveals another advantage of H2DP.

caption.p: Delivery ratio against network size (1 m/s, 0.2 pkts/s, tH=2 s)#a Dense topology

p.italic: Number of packets per node against network size for both dense and sparse topologies

caption.p: Performance against network size (1 m/s, 0.2 pkts/s, tH=2 s)#a Mean delay

sec.p: Fig. 5a illustrates mean delay, that is, the average delay involved in receiving a broadcast message, which is another important performance metric. In dense networks, H2DP induces smaller delays by minimising the number of duplicate packets. This minimisation has a twofold impact; on the one hand alleviates congestion and therefore smaller queuing delays occur, while on the other hand medium access delay is minimised as a result of less contention. The increasing trend of delay with respect to network size is ascribed to the increasing number of hops involved in a broadcast. As a result, longer delays are evident in sparse networks where paths consist of more hops due to the reduced connectivity. In this case, the performance of all schemes is similar since delay is dominated by the number of hops.

Finally, in Fig. 5b we present the normalised byte overhead, that is, the average number of bytes transmitted in the network during the broadcast of a message. This metric evaluates the impact of piggybacking the history on the packet's header. Surprisingly, H2DP induces less bytes in the dense topology scenario while its performance is close to the other schemes in sparse networks. Bear in mind that the presented results represent the worst-case scenario for H2DP since the optimisation for packet history representation, proposed in Section 3.2, has not been used. Instead, we used 4 bytes for each address piggybacked on the packet's header. The significantly reduced number of transmissions (Fig. 2) justifies H2DP's performance. Although packets of more bytes are created, the overall balance is positive. It should be pointed out that, in contention-based networks, the bandwidth is consumed by the access delay which is dominant compared to the transmission delay. Keeping in mind that access delay depends on the number of packet transmissions and transmission delay depends on the packet size, it is clear that minimising the number of transmissions has a greater impact on bandwidth savings.

sec.title: Resilience to mobility
sec.p: It is important for schemes that use neighbourhood information, such as DP, to evaluate their resilience to high mobility. Therefore in this section, we will investigate the impact of (a) node mobility and (b) hello interval, that is, the rate at which topology information is refreshed.

sec.title: Impact of mobility
sec.p: In Fig. 6a the delivery ratio for all algorithms is presented against node mobility for sparse and dense networks. In sparse networks, mobility severely affects all algorithms since neighbourhood information quickly becomes stale. The impact of mobility is greater in TDP and H2DP. More specifically, although H2DP is superior to DP (by ∼0.4%) when mobility is low, its performance lacks ∼0.4% when mobility is 20 m/s. Similar performance is witnessed for TDP. This behaviour is ascribed to the fact that 2-hop neighbourhood information, which has an increased invalidation rate compared to 1-hop neighbourhood, is used to minimise U(v). However, in dense networks, H2DP preserves its advantage over all algorithms through the entire mobility range. In this case, although the neighbourhood information is invalidated, the increased node connectivity provides multiple paths (path diversity) that enable all algorithms to efficiently deliver the broadcast message. These results indicate that algorithms utilising 2-hop neighbourhood may become less efficient in sparse networks of increased mobility (>20 m/s) such as VANETs. In Section 6, we propose an optimised version of H2DP that presents increased resilience to mobility.

b Hello interval (20 m/s, 100 nodes, 0.2 pkts/s) for dense and sparse networks

sec.title: Impact of hello interval
sec.p: The impact of mobility depends on the refresh rate of neighbourhood information, that is, the hello interval. A short hello interval provides the means for dealing with performance degradation in highly mobile networks. In Fig. 5b, the delivery ratio is presented against the hello interval for all algorithms in networks of high mobility (20 m/s). As expected, long hello intervals cause degradation in performance of all schemes; however, the impact is more intense on H2DP and TDP because 2-hop neighbourhood is used. Again, the impact of hello interval is heavier in sparse networks because of the reduced path diversity. Shorter hello intervals are in favour of H2DP in both dense and sparse networks. Although all schemes improve their performance, due to more accurate neighbourhood information, the improvement in H2DP is sharper, since it is combined with reduced levels of congestion due to the minimisation of elected forwarding nodes. On the other hand, all other schemes produce more transmissions therefore part of their improvement is nullified by increased levels of collisions. This is evident in a more clear way in the case of dense networks where congestion is heavier than in sparse networks. In this case, only H2DP improves its performance for hello intervals of 1–2 s. On the contrary, all other schemes do not improve due to congestion. Finally, when the hello interval is 0.5 s (there will be more hello messages and therefore more collisions), the performance of all schemes is degraded. It is worth mentioning that the congestion in DP is so high that shorter hello intervals have the opposite effect, that is, reduction in delivery ratio. According to the presented results, it is clear that H2DP may utilise shorter hello intervals in sparse and highly mobile environments in order to improve its performance in terms of delivery ratio. The cost of using a shorter hello interval may be compensated by the reduced packet redundancy witnessed in Figs. 5 and 6.

sec.title: Performance under congestion
sec.p: In this section we evaluate the performance under conditions of increased congestion. Such conditions are frequently present in MANETs due to the limited bandwidth. In Fig. 7, the performance of all algorithms is presented against the broadcast rate. As expected, all schemes are heavily affected. As far as the delivery ratio is concerned (Fig. 7a), DP rapidly collapses, especially in dense networks since the increased network connectivity aggravates congestion. H2DP produces less duplicate packets and therefore is able to cope with congestion more effectively. As a result, H2DP achieves an improvement of ∼3.5% in the sparse and ∼6.5% in the dense network compared to TDP, which is the second performer. The improvement compared to DP reaches up to ∼13.5% in the dense network and ∼6% in the sparse. A confirmation of congestion is the mean delay, presented in Fig. 7b. When broadcast rate is above 1 pkt/s, delay rapidly increases because longer queues are formed and frequent activity in the medium increases access delay. When the network is heavily congested (2 pkt/s) only H2DP achieves an acceptable delay (∼160 ms) and at the same time exhibits the best delivery ratio (Fig. 7a).

caption.p: Performance against broadcast rate (1 m/s, 100 nodes, tH=2 s)#a Delivery ratio

sec.title: History-based DP
sec.p:
The performance evaluation of H2DP has brought to light its reduced resilience to highly mobile (>20 m/s) and sparse networks. This behaviour stems from the fact that H2DP, when building Hv(p) in node v, makes the optimistic assumption that every node in N(N(v)) has already or will receive p. However, stale neighbourhood information, which is frequent in highly mobile environments, may invalidate the aforementioned assumption. To overcome this shortcoming, we propose to use only N(v) in forming the packet history, that is
$$H^v \lpar p\rpar =\bigcup\limits_{\forall w \in P^v \lpar p\rpar } N\lpar w\rpar \eqno(10)$$

The intuition is that resilience to mobility will be increased since N(v) has a smaller invalidation rate compared to N(N(v)). We call the resulting DP scheme, HDP. HDP takes a more conservative approach compared to H2DP. It only makes the assumption that all nodes in N(w), ∀w∈Hv(p) have already received p. Clearly, the approach of HDP is to tradeoff reduction of forward nodes for delivery efficiency. This can also be verified by (2), (10) and (7); the history of HDP is smaller than that of H2DP; therefore U(v) is bigger in HDP. As a result, the approximation factor is worse than that of H2DP.

Fig. 8a illustrates the delivery ratio and the number of forward nodes for HDP with respect to node mobility, whereas Fig. 8b presents the same performance metrics against the hello interval when mobility is fixed to 20 m/s. Both experiments are carried out in sparse networks. HDP is compared with H2DP and DP, which presents the best resilience to highly mobile and sparse networks. The approach of HDP is proved to be effective since it outperforms DP with respect to delivery ratio even for the highest mobility. Moreover, this is accomplished in parallel to a reduction of the number of forward nodes that ranges in ∼13.5–15.5% for all mobility levels. This result confirms the tradeoff that HDP introduces, since its performance lies between that of DP and H2DP. The resilience of HDP to mobility is also confirmed by Fig. 8b, where the impact of hello interval is illustrated. Even for long intervals HDP preserves its superiority over both DP and H2DP. At the same time, even though HDP produces more forward nodes compared to H2DP, it still manages an impressive reduction that reaches up to 18.5% compared to DP.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper a new approach to DP, called H2DP, has been proposed for minimising the redundant transmissions during broadcasting. H2DP makes the observation that the history of a packet may be used for minimising the set of forwarding nodes in DP-based schemes. The analysis of H2DP as well as its extensive simulation study have confirmed its improved performance compared to existing DP schemes with respect not only to the minimisation of broadcasting cost but also to the ability to deliver a broadcast message. Furthermore, an optimisation of H2DP, tailored for highly mobile and sparse networks, has been proposed and proved to be effective in increasing the resilience to mobility.
